attributes.title: Spinning Wheel Chair (1886)
attributes.description:
Attributed to William B. Savage, Boston, active ca. 1880-90
Gift of Elizabeth Morris Smith

This chair is made entirely out of discarded spinning wheel parts. While unique in design, it was not particularly rare in the late 19c, when antiques and references to pre-industrial America became popular as part of what we call the "Colonial Revival" movement today. 

*Click on the dots to see how the bowl is associated with each place
Gifted to the RISD museum by Elizabeth Morris Smith, a member of a politically prominent family in Newport since the 1700s, in memory of her mother.
attributes.title: Owned by Elizabeth Morris Smith

attributes.description:
When advertising this chair, William Savage quoted "The Courtship of Miles Standish," an 1858 narrative poem by American poet Henry Wadsworth Longfellow: "So as she sat at her wheel one afternoon in the autumn, Alden, who opposite sat, and was watching her dexterous fingers, As if the thread she was spinning were that of his life and his fortune." 
The poem portrays a romanticized image of the early days of Plymouth Colony, a colonial settlement established in America by the Mayflower Pilgrims. This connection of the spinning wheel to courtship made Savage’s chairs popular as wedding gifts.
attributes.title: Why the spinning wheel?

attributes.description: A spinning wheel displayed in the Philadelphia Exposition of 1876 was reported in Harper's Weekly to have been "a wheel that may have been the one over which the Puritan Maiden leaned while the lovemaking that was intended to be vicarious became real." This was a reference to a popular 1858 poem by Henry Wadsworth Longfellow, "The Courtship of Miles Standish."
attributes.title: Why the spinning wheel?

attributes.description: While currently displayed in Pendleton House, the spinning wheel chair was not collected by Charles L. Pendleton (1846-1904) himself, who donated his collection to the RISD Museum in 1904. Pendleton himself did not have interest in Colonial Revival style furniture, which became the focus of attention for a subsequent generation of collectors.
attributes.title: 1978 RISD Museum

attributes.description:
By the time this piece was made, spinning wheels 
had been out of use in homes for many years but were becoming popular as antiques. Savage collected damaged spinning wheels of little commercial value and used the parts to make his chairs.
